VI (02/10/2001 10:32:01 AM)
	I have seen this error before.
	In all likely hood you are trying to span multiple columns but you have not created a GridLayout with multiple columns.
	(run the example below).

	You will also get a null pointer exception if you have specified a number of columns but you try to span columns beyond the available range
	e.g.  You have a 3 column GridLayout and you have added two widgets and you are trying to have a third widget that spans two columns.
	This can't work because there is only one column left.
	(run the example below and uncomment the "layout.numColumns = 3" line.

public static void main (String [] args) {
	Display display = new Display ();
	Shell shell = new Shell (display);
	GridLayout layout = new GridLayout();
	//layout.numColumns = 3;
	shell.setLayout(layout);
	
	Button b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH);
	b.setText("button 1");
	b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH);
	b.setText("button 2");
	b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH);
	b.setText("button 3");
	GridData data = new GridData();
	data.horizontalSpan = 2;
	shell.open ();
	while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {
		if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();
	}
	display.dispose ();
}

	The fix is to be careful about spanning columns and be sure that there are enough columns there to span.
	SWT can throw a different kind of exception with more information but it is still an error and we will throw an exception.

This is actually a problem with the client code.  In 
DebugTestsSelectionDialog.createDialogArea() a GridLayout ("columnLay") is 
created and then used twice as a composite layout (once within the same method, 
and is passed to #createHeader(...) and used there as well).

Layout objects cannot be reused, so the fix is to create a new one in 
#createHeader(...) and use it there instead of receiving the instance created 
in #createDialogArea().  It's fluky that this works on Windows.  No SWT change 
required.
